defs.docs: Simple 2D geometric primitives on top of euclid.

attributes.value: deny(bare_trait_objects)
allow(clippy :: many_single_char_names)
allow(clippy :: let_and_return)
! Simple 2D geometric primitives on top of euclid.
! This crate is reexported in [lyon](https://docs.rs/lyon/).
! # Overview.
! This crate implements some of the maths to work with:
! - lines and line segments,
! - quadratic and cubic bézier curves,
! - elliptic arcs,
! - triangles.
! # Flattening
! Flattening is the action of approximating a curve with a succession of line segments.
! <svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 120 30" height="30mm" width="120mm">

!   <text style="line-height:6.61458302px" x="35.74" y="284.49" font-size="5.29" font-family="Sans" letter-spacing="0" word-spacing="0" fill="#b3b3b3" stroke-width=".26" transform="translate(19.595 -267)">
!   </text>
! </svg>
! The flattening algorithm implemented in this crate is based on the paper
! [Fast, Precise Flattening of Cubic Bézier Segment Offset Curves](http://cis.usouthal.edu/~hain/general/Publications/Bezier/Bezier%20Offset%20Curves.pdf).
! It tends to produce a better approximations than the usual recursive subdivision approach (or
! in other words, it generates less segments for a given tolerance threshold).
! The tolerance threshold taken as input by the flattening algorithms corresponds
! to the maximum distance between the curve and its linear approximation.
! The smaller the tolerance is, the more precise the approximation and the more segments
! are generated. This value is typically chosen in function of the zoom level.
! <svg viewBox="0 0 47.5 13.2" height="100" width="350" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
!   <path d="M-1.97 9.3C14.28 1.03 37.36 1.7 49.7 11.4" fill="none" stroke="#00d400" stroke-width=".57" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-dasharray="4.6, 2.291434"/>
!   <g fill="none" stroke="#ff7f2a" stroke-width=".26">
! </svg>
! The figure above shows a close up on a curve (the dotted line) and its linear
! approximation (the black segments). The tolerance threshold is represented by
! the light green area and the orange arrow.

An iterator over a generic curve segment that yields line segments approximating the
 curve for a given approximation threshold.

/ destination.

defs.name: cubic_intersections_t
defs.docs: Computes the intersections (if any) between this segment and another one.

attributes.value: / Computes the intersections (if any) between this segment and another one.
/ The result is provided in the form of the `t` parameters of each point along the curves. To
/ get the intersection points, sample the curves at the corresponding values.
/ Returns endpoint intersections where an endpoint intersects the interior of the other curve,
/ but not endpoint/endpoint intersections.
/ Returns no intersections if either curve is a point.

defs.name: cubic_intersections
defs.docs: Computes the intersection points (if any) between this segment and another one.

attributes.value: / Computes the intersection points (if any) between this segment and another one.

defs.name: quadratic_intersections_t
defs.docs: Computes the intersections (if any) between this segment a quadratic bézier segment.

attributes.value: / Computes the intersections (if any) between this segment a quadratic bézier segment.
/ The result is provided in the form of the `t` parameters of each point along the curves. To
/ get the intersection points, sample the curves at the corresponding values.
/ Returns endpoint intersections where an endpoint intersects the interior of the other curve,
/ but not endpoint/endpoint intersections.
/ Returns no intersections if either curve is a point.

defs.name: quadratic_intersections
defs.docs: Computes the intersection points (if any) between this segment and a quadratic bézier segment.

attributes.value: / Computes the intersection points (if any) between this segment and a quadratic bézier segment.

defs.name: line_intersections_t
defs.docs: Computes the intersections (if any) between this segment and a line.

attributes.value: / Computes the intersections (if any) between this segment and a line.
/ The result is provided in the form of the `t` parameters of each
/ point along curve. To get the intersection points, sample the curve
/ at the corresponding values.

attributes.value: / Computes the intersection points (if any) between this segment and a line.

defs.name: single_curve_approximation
defs.docs:
This is terrible as a general approximation but works if the cubic
 curve does not have inflection points and is "flat" enough. Typically
 usables after subdiving the curve a few times.

attributes.value: / This is terrible as a general approximation but works if the cubic
/ curve does not have inflection points and is "flat" enough. Typically
/ usables after subdiving the curve a few times.

Evaluates an upper bound on the maximum distance between the curve
 and its quadratic approximation obtained using the single curve approximation.

attributes.value: / Evaluates an upper bound on the maximum distance between the curve
/ and its quadratic approximation obtained using the single curve approximation.

attributes.value: / Sample the x coordinate of the curve at t (expecting t between 0 and 1).

defs.name: y
defs.docs: Sample the y coordinate of the curve at t (expecting t between 0 and 1).

attributes.value: / Sample the y coordinate of the curve at t (expecting t between 0 and 1).

defs.name: derivative
defs.docs: Sample the curve's derivative at t (expecting t between 0 and 1).

attributes.value: / Sample the curve's derivative at t (expecting t between 0 and 1).

defs.name: dx
defs.docs: Sample the x coordinate of the curve's derivative at t (expecting t between 0 and 1).

attributes.value: / Sample the x coordinate of the curve's derivative at t (expecting t between 0 and 1).

defs.name: dy
defs.docs: Sample the y coordinate of the curve's derivative at t (expecting t between 0 and 1).

attributes.value: / Sample the y coordinate of the curve's derivative at t (expecting t between 0 and 1).

defs.name: flip
defs.docs: Swap the beginning and the end of the segment.

attributes.value: / Swap the beginning and the end of the segment.

defs.name: y_maximum_t
defs.docs: Find the advancement of the y-most position in the curve.

attributes.value: / Find the advancement of the y-most position in the curve.
/ This returns the advancement along the curve, not the actual y position.

defs.name: y_minimum_t
defs.docs: Find the advancement of the y-least position in the curve.

attributes.value: / Find the advancement of the y-least position in the curve.
/ This returns the advancement along the curve, not the actual y position.

defs.name: local_y_extremum_t
defs.docs: Return the y inflection point or None if this curve is y-monotonic.

attributes.value: / Return the y inflection point or None if this curve is y-monotonic.

defs.name: x_maximum_t
defs.docs: Find the advancement of the x-most position in the curve.

attributes.value: / Find the advancement of the x-most position in the curve.
/ This returns the advancement along the curve, not the actual x position.

defs.name: x_minimum_t
defs.docs: Find the advancement of the x-least position in the curve.

attributes.value: / Find the advancement of the x-least position in the curve.
/ This returns the advancement along the curve, not the actual x position.

defs.name: local_x_extremum_t
defs.docs: Return the x inflection point or None if this curve is x-monotonic.

attributes.value: / Return the x inflection point or None if this curve is x-monotonic.

defs.name: split_range
defs.docs: Return the sub-curve inside a given range of t.

attributes.value: / Return the sub-curve inside a given range of t.
/ This is equivalent splitting at the range's end points.

defs.name: split
defs.docs: Split this curve into two sub-curves.

attributes.value: / Split this curve into two sub-curves.

defs.name: before_split
defs.docs: Return the curve before the split point.

attributes.value: / Return the curve before the split point.

defs.name: after_split
defs.docs: Return the curve after the split point.

attributes.value: / Return the curve after the split point.

defs.name: to_cubic
defs.docs: Elevate this curve to a third order bézier.

attributes.value: / Elevate this curve to a third order bézier.
inline

defs.name: fat_line
defs.docs: Computes a "fat line" of this segment.

attributes.value: / Computes a "fat line" of this segment.
/ A fat line is two conservative lines between which the segment
/ is fully contained.

defs.name: transformed
defs.docs: Applies the transform to this curve and returns the results.

attributes.value: / Applies the transform to this curve and returns the results.
inline

defs.name: flattening_step
defs.docs:
Find the interval of the beginning of the curve that can be approximated with a
 line segment.

attributes.value: / Find the interval of the beginning of the curve that can be approximated with a
/ line segment.

defs.name: for_each_flattened
defs.docs:
Compute a flattened approximation of the curve, invoking a callback at
 each step.

attributes.value: / Compute a flattened approximation of the curve, invoking a callback at
/ each step.
/ The callback takes the point on the curve at each step.
/ This implements the algorithm described by Raph Levien at
/ https://raphlinus.github.io/graphics/curves/2019/12/23/flatten-quadbez.html

defs.name: for_each_flattened_t
defs.docs:
Compute a flattened approximation of the curve, invoking a callback at
 each step.

attributes.value: / Compute a flattened approximation of the curve, invoking a callback at
/ each step.
/ The callback takes the curve parameter at each step.
/ This implements the algorithm described by Raph Levien at
/ https://raphlinus.github.io/graphics/curves/2019/12/23/flatten-quadbez.html

defs.name: for_each_flattened_with_t
defs.docs:
Compute a flattened approximation of the curve, invoking a callback at
 each step.

attributes.value: / Compute a flattened approximation of the curve, invoking a callback at
/ each step.
/ The callback takes the point and corresponding curve parameter at each step.
/ This implements the algorithm described by Raph Levien at
/ https://raphlinus.github.io/graphics/curves/2019/12/23/flatten-quadbez.html

defs.name: flattened
defs.docs:
Returns the flattened representation of the curve as an iterator, starting *after* the
 current point.

attributes.value: / Returns the flattened representation of the curve as an iterator, starting *after* the
/ current point.

defs.name: flattened_t
defs.docs:
Returns the flattened representation of the curve as an iterator, starting *after* the
 current point.

attributes.value: / Returns the flattened representation of the curve as an iterator, starting *after* the
/ current point.

defs.name: for_each_monotonic_t
defs.docs: Invokes a callback between each monotonic part of the segment.

attributes.value: / Invokes a callback between each monotonic part of the segment.

defs.name: for_each_monotonic_range
defs.docs: Invokes a callback for each monotonic part of the segment..

attributes.value: / Invokes a callback for each monotonic part of the segment..

defs.name: approximate_length
defs.docs: Compute the length of the segment using a flattened approximation.

attributes.value: / Compute the length of the segment using a flattened approximation.

defs.name: bounding_triangle
defs.docs: Returns a triangle containing this curve segment.

attributes.value: / Returns a triangle containing this curve segment.

defs.name: fast_bounding_rect
defs.docs: Returns a conservative rectangle that contains the curve.

attributes.value: / Returns a conservative rectangle that contains the curve.

defs.name: fast_bounding_range_x
defs.docs: Returns a conservative range of x this curve is contained in.

attributes.value: / Returns a conservative range of x this curve is contained in.

defs.name: fast_bounding_range_y
defs.docs: Returns a conservative range of y this curve is contained in.

attributes.value: / Returns a conservative range of y this curve is contained in.

defs.name: bounding_rect
defs.docs: Returns the smallest rectangle the curve is contained in

defs.name: bounding_range_x
defs.docs: Returns the smallest range of x this curve is contained in.

defs.name: bounding_range_y
defs.docs: Returns the smallest range of y this curve is contained in.

attributes.value: / Returns the smallest range of y this curve is contained in.

defs.name: assume_monotonic
defs.docs:
Cast this curve into a monotonic curve without checking that the monotonicity
 assumption is correct.

attributes.value: / Cast this curve into a monotonic curve without checking that the monotonicity
/ assumption is correct.

defs.name: is_x_monotonic
defs.docs: Returns whether this segment is monotonic on the x axis.

attributes.value: / Returns whether this segment is monotonic on the x axis.

defs.name: is_y_monotonic
defs.docs: Returns whether this segment is monotonic on the y axis.

attributes.value: / Returns whether this segment is monotonic on the y axis.

defs.name: is_monotonic
defs.docs: Returns whether this segment is fully monotonic.

attributes.value: / Returns whether this segment is fully monotonic.

defs.name: line_intersections_t
defs.docs: Computes the intersections (if any) between this segment a line.

attributes.value: / Computes the intersections (if any) between this segment a line.
/ The result is provided in the form of the `t` parameters of each
/ point along curve. To get the intersection points, sample the curve
/ at the corresponding values.

defs.name: line_intersections
defs.docs: Computes the intersection points (if any) between this segment a line.

attributes.value: / Computes the intersection points (if any) between this segment a line.

defs.name: line_segment_intersections_t
defs.docs: Computes the intersections (if any) between this segment a line segment.

attributes.value: / Computes the intersections (if any) between this segment a line segment.
/ The result is provided in the form of the `t` parameters of each
/ point along curve and segment. To get the intersection points, sample
/ the segments at the corresponding values.
inline
inline

defs.name: directed_angle
defs.docs:
Angle between vectors v1 and v2 (oriented clockwise assyming y points downwards).
 The result is a number between `0` and `2 * PI`.

attributes.value: / Angle between vectors v1 and v2 (oriented clockwise assyming y points downwards).
/ The result is a number between `0` and `2 * PI`.
/ ex: `directed_angle([0,1], [1,0]) = 3/2 Pi rad`
/ ```text
/              v
/ Or, assuming y points upwards:
/ `directed_angle([0,-1], [1,0]) = 1/2 Pi rad`
/ ```text
/     x        v-
inline

SubAssign + MulAssign + DivAssign
